abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Research Project for
            Ethiopia achieved a satisfactory overall outcome,
            particularly when viewed against the backdrop of the
            protracted civil strife, breakdown in socio-economic
            infrastructure, and weakened sectorial institutions. The IDA
            performed satisfactorily throughout the project cycle. Its
            active supervision, particularly during the last 2 years of
            the project (1993 to 1994), contributed significantly to the
            final result. The Borrower's performance was mostly
            satisfactory. There were initial difficulties and delays in
            procurement, the recruitment of technical assistance, the
            commencement of training activities, and the compliance with
            other covenants. The sustainability of the major initiatives
            under the project is likely, thanks to the Government's
            commitment to agricultural research and extension. The
            project originally planned for a six year duration from 1984
            to 1991, but was delayed twice up to 1994 due to the civil
            war. The pace of implementation picked up rapidly after
            mid-1991. The main lessons learned are institutional: to
            optimize the results of institutional development measures
            such as staff training, a well-designed training plan, with
            clearly articulated needs and priorities, should be prepared
            with IDA during appraisal. Assurances should be obtained
            regarding implementation in the event that the project
            management team is overhauled due to a force majeure, with
            renegotiation or cancellation as possible consequences of
            failure. Implementing institutions should be cognizant of
            IDA's procurement and disbursement procedures. Up-front
            training of staff and backup personnel in Bank procedures is
            recommended. In order to enhance the benefits from technical
            assistance, the arrival of consultants should be
            synchronized with the availability of equipment.

docna.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Agricultural Research Project :
            Credit 1521 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Ethiopia - Agricultural Research
            Project : Credit 1521 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
Over five years the Agricultural
            Research Project will:  (i) strengthen field crop and coffee
            research; (ii) strengthen irrigation/salinity research and
            animal husbandry and pasture research; (iii) improve
            adaptive research to translate findings into messages
            suitable for farmers; and (iv) rehabilitate research station
            plant and equipment.  It will also; (v) improve headquarters
            support services to the stations; and (vi) provide technical
            assistance and strengthen training programs.  The primary
            focus of the project will be on field crop and coffee
            research in high potential areas, since this research offers
            opportunities for quicker returns than would be obtainable
            from research in other subsectors. Increased crop production
            in high potential areas would help stimulate economy-wide
            growth and also to generate surplus food to cope with
            frequent shortages in drought-prone areas.
